properties.name: Botetourt County Courthouse
properties.Desc: This is the 4th such building to occupy the current site. The first was a log structure, second was erected in 1818 and was designed by Thomas Jefferson. The third courthouse, built in 1845, was destroyed by a fire in 1970, although records dating back to 1970 survived within the building's vault.

properties.name: Fincastle Presbyterian Church and Cemetery
properties.Desc: On this site is the original Church of England building erected in 1771. The Presbyterian congregation began in 1754 as the Sinking Spring Congregation. In 1840, the entrance was changed from facing east to facing south, and the Greek Revival Style columns and tall steeple were added.

properties.name: Israel Christian House
properties.Desc: Thought to be the oldest house in Fincastle, the original structure is a one-story log building constrcuted in 1772 by Israel Christian. A second floor was added above the log structure sometime later. Christian willed the home to one of his slaves, Becky Holmes. The first black school may have been in the basement room of this house and according to published accounts, the first black church services were held in an adjoining room. In 1811, a post and beam addition was constructred to the east of the log structure. A rear addition was added in the late 1800s. Interior rooms are connected directly to each other with no hallways.

properties.name: Backenstoe House
properties.Desc: Originally a two story structure built of logs and covered with clapboard. House shown on Gray's 1880 map of Fincastle as a one-room structure with a porch

properties.name: Peck Cottage
properties.Desc: One of the very early small log homes clustered around the town spring. A simple log structure of rough cut logs that are exposed in the original front room and loft. Original casement windows can be seen in the loft. A dugout for food storage still remains. The original dimension of the one-room house was 16x20 feet.

properties.name: Hancock House
properties.Desc: This cottage-type house was built by George Hancock of Santillane. It is believed he built this house for use by tradesmen. The original structure is log and consisted of two rooms with a sleeping loft. The floors are wide board planks.

properties.name: Stoner House
properties.Desc: The left-side of this house is believed to have been built as early as 1790 as identified on the earliest maps of Fincastle. The right-side addition was added in the 1850s. There is a distinctive difference between the brick work on the left and right sides.

properties.name: Ware House
properties.Desc: The front two-story rooms are log construction. The kitchen and dining rooms were added in the early 1800s and back rooms in the mid-1900s

properties.name: Sally Douglas House
properties.Desc: An early house that is believed to have been a potter's house. Two large fireplaces are evidence of pottery making.

properties.name: Crowder House
properties.Desc: Restored by HFI in 1976 for $8,000 to the original log structure. Stuart Carter gave the house to HFI.

properties.name: Peck Corner House
properties.Desc: Early small log home near the town spring built on land deeded from Israel Christian to George Hancock

properties.name: Thompson-Carper-Slicer House
properties.Desc: A log shop was built in 1792, a brick house in 1830, and a frame addition in 1880. This is one of the few brick homes with Georgian characteristics in Fincastle.

properties.name: Old Saddler Shop
properties.Desc: Houses along Church Street are some of the earliest remaining dwellings in Fincastle. These buildings were able to escape the two great fires that swept the town in 1820 and again in 1870. The bottom part of the house was the shop and the upper floors were used as living quarters. In 1983, HFI purchased and restored the Saddler's Shop for $30,000

properties.name: James Matten Early Cabin
properties.Desc: Log portion of this building was built between 1796 and 1798 of rough-hewn logs by the town tailor, James Matten Early and was restored by HFI. The front log room contains the kitchen, dining, sleeping, and gathering area with a stone fireplace. A sleeping loft is above. In 1982, HFI received a $25,000 grant from the Virginia Historic Landmarks Commission and completed restoration in 1987 with an additional $53,000 contributed by HFI. The cabin was a gift to HFI from Aurich Bolton.

properties.name: Helms-Ayers House
properties.Desc: Originally was constructed as a four room log cabin. HFI purchased and later sold the home with protective covenants in 1987.

properties.name: Museum Building
properties.Desc: Located in Court House Square, this building houses the Botetourt County Museum. One room is thought to be the law office of General James Breckinridge.

properties.name: Kyle House
properties.Desc: Built by Robert Kyle. The front door opened directly onto the street. Part of house was destroyed in fire, exposing the fireplace on the west side. Restored in 2012. Bungalows west of the Kyle House were built by Mr. French Bolton of Academy Hill for his sons. Once run as a tavern by Mrs. Backus, an early tavern owner.

properties.name: Godwin Cemetary
properties.Desc: Earliest graves date from the mid 1800s and are located along Church Street, on land purchased by James Godwin in 1801 for a family graveyard. A portion of his property was deeded to John Slicer in 1891 for his family burials. At the top of the hill was land owned by A.E.G. Aurik, which passed to the Bolton Family. By 1898, the Godwin Cemetery Trustees acquired the properties. The honey locust tree near the entrance of the church is listed on the American Forests Big Tree Registry.

properties.name: Lewis Houseman House
properties.Desc: Built by a local store owner. Houseman's store was at the northeast corner of Main and Roanoke Street. This house has four major fireplaces but the chimneys are not visible from Main Street. The federal style house was later embellished with gingerbread railings and a center medallion

properties.name: Western Hotel
properties.Desc: A destination hotel through the early 1900s, it also served as the Federal Courthouse. The brick building was built after the great fire of 1870, which started in the hotel stable. The earlier hotel was a wooden structure.

properties.name: Tavern
properties.Desc: The site of entertainment for hotel guests and locals. An addition was burned in 1968 and was the first restoration of Historical Fincastle, Incorporated.

properties.name: Douglas Building
properties.Desc: Two story brick building with double front porches built on a stone foundation that envloses a basement dating to the 1820s. The building burned in an 1870 fire and was rebuilt on the old foundation. It was restored by HFI in 1977 with protective covenants and sold in 1981.

properties.name: Ammen House
properties.Desc: Recipient of Roanoke Valley Preservation Foudation's 2008 Renovation Award. Built by Benjamin Ammen close to his woolen mill. The woodwork in this Federal style has Gothic arches on the living room mantelpiece and Adam fan over front door. It has 10-foot ceilings, rooms that measure 20x20 and heart of pine floors.

properties.name: Kyle House/Bolton's Store
properties.Desc: Robert Kyle, a prosperous landowner and merchant, built this house as a residence and a store. In 1833, the property was operated as a hotel. From 1914 until the 1970s, the house was known as Bolton's Store. The three-story brick structure has a hand-laid limestone foundation. Interior walls are also brick, covered by plaster. The building was originally L-shaped with a separate outdoor kitchen. Limestone frames the tops and bottoms of the doors and windows. The building is best known for exquisitely carved interior woodwork on fireplace mantels, archways, door frames, and the large scale three-story open staircase. Tradition has it that an itinerant German woodcarver rendered the carvings. Floor and ceiling beams are hand-hewn and pegged. A prominent feature is the large second-story ballrom

properties.name: Mays Cottage
properties.Desc: Built by F.H. Mays and includes a mantel and beams from earlier dwellings in other parts of Virginia. It survived a fire which destroyed an adjacent home.

properties.name: Carper House
properties.Desc: A back section dates to 1831. The front Victorian addition was added to the structure between 1890 and 1904.

properties.name: Hatter's Shop
properties.Desc: Housed the shop on the first floor with living quarters on the second floor

properties.name: Hedrick House
properties.Desc: The building was originally a chair factory, and was used as a dressmaker's and tailor's shop in later years by the Hedrick family. Confederate uniforms were made in this house and later the first Virginia Polytechnic Institute uniforms were created here. Fincastle was considered as one of the potential sites for VPI.

properties.name: Aspen Hill
properties.Desc: Built by Captain Sam Figgat in classical style called "Tuscan idiom" or Italianate architecture. The once separate kitchen has been connected by a passageway, known because the dining windows look out to a hall.

properties.name: St. Mark's Episcopal Church
properties.Desc: In 1837, the Vestry of the Botetourt Anglican Parish bought land on the west side of Roanoke Street in Fincastle for the sum of $175. Gothic influence shows in its pointed arches over the doorway and windows; however, the interior is traditionally colonial in style. The electrified lighting fixtures are probably original to the building. The church still has the King George III era communion service which dates from the early church and was preserved during the Civil War by the Breckinridge family.

properties.name: Blacksmith Shop/Wysong Park
properties.Desc: Restored in 1978 by HFI and the Wysong family whose ancestor, Fiatt Wysong, was a blacksmith in Fincastle. It contains many old blacksmith tools. The Park was donated by Wysong descendants to HFI.

properties.name: Fincastle United Methodist Church
properties.Desc: The congregation was formed in 1789. The orginal building was condemned, torn down with the aid of oxen teams, and replaced by the present Greek Revival style structure in 1840 following a great revival conducted by William Craft. The Botetourt Circuit was formed in 1789 under Bishop Fincis Asbury's leadership.

properties.name: Hammit House
properties.Desc: This is a wonderful example of early Fincastle structures. The house has been restored to protect the original structure. Its plants area  wonderful example of a cottage-type garden.

properties.name: Price House
properties.Desc: Built by Judge Hudson, this Victorian style has 11 ft. ceilings on the first floor, 16 ft. ceilings on the 2nd floor, multi-storied bay windows, and a suspended staircase. Ornate wrought iron over the windows adds a New Orleans influence.

properties.name: Gray House
properties.Desc: Built by Rev. Gray, a Baptist minister, the original structure burned in 1870. The rebuilt house has bay windows, four full porches, upper and lower, in front and back, and two separate basements.

properties.name: Oliver House
properties.Desc: Originally a two room house weith four additional rooms added later.

properties.name: Hayth Hotel
properties.Desc: Accommodated up to 150 guyests and was the scene of costume balls, musicales, and dances in the ballroom that no longer exists. A destination hotel to avoid the heat and mosquitoes of the south. 1880 room rates were $25 a month. HFI purchased and resold the house with protective covenants in 1981.

properties.name: Bank of Fincastle
properties.Desc: Botetourt County's oldest bank was originally named the Farmers Bank. The Bank of Fincastle was founded on September 22, 1875 and moved to this location in 1908. Only one other Fincastle business has been in operation longer - the Fincastle Herald.

properties.name: Methodist Parsonage
properties.Desc: This house was used as a parsonage from 1891 - 1969.

properties.name: Smith-Switzer House
properties.Desc: Built after the original dwelling was destroyed by a fire. The iron work reflects the New Orleans influence.

properties.name: Godwin Cottage
properties.Desc: An example of Federal architecture and believed to have been based on a design by Thomas Jefferson. Built by Dr. Williams and sold to Dr. Godwin, practicing physicians in Fincastle.

properties.name: Figgat House and Law Offices
properties.Desc: Built by Captain Jim Figgat with 18 inch brick outer walls, high ceilings, and imported marble fireplaces is built in the Victorian style. The widow's walk on the top is very unusual architecture in the area.

properties.name: Carper House
properties.Desc: Built by George W. Carper as a wedding gift for one of his daughters, Mrs. John Slicer, who refused to live in it. It was later sold to the Presbyterian congregation for use as their manse.

properties.name: The Luster Building
properties.Desc: Completed in 1894 and house the J.O. Luster Tin and Stove Establishment. Iron cornice, window capping on the front of the building, and stained and penciled brickwork survives to this day. The bay window was constructed to provide light for a dentist, and was later used by the first telephone operators in the region.

properties.name: Boarding House
properties.Desc: Used in part as a tourist-boarding house. Features ornamental trim on the top porch and a medallion at the 2nd floor eave near the driveway.

properties.name: Reinhart-Luster House
properties.Desc: This large house has wide center hallway and stairway. The structure was a female academy.

properties.name: Fincastle Baptist Church
properties.Desc: Organized in August 1831 under Absalom Dempsey. Construction began in January 1891 in Victorian Romanesque style. This structure was used by the congregation until 2005 when they outgrew the facilities. It is now a private residence

properties.name: Old Jail Building
properties.Desc: Restored by HFI after the first Fall Festival in 1968, it is best known for its New Orleans-influenced iron and grill work. In early times, the jailer lived downstairs, women prisoners were on the second floor, and men on the third. The ceiling of the Jailer's quarters is steel reinforced concrete to prevent an inmate from 'digging out of jail'. It ceased to be a jail in 1962 and was used as a library.

properties.name: Academy Hill
properties.Desc: One of Fincastle's most unique houses. The Victorian house was constructed in the shape of a cross and has encircling porches and large airy rooms with front and back stairways. It has a 3-story turret, referred to as a widow's walk, and is fronted by a stone wall.

properties.name: Prospect Hill
properties.Desc: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places and with the Virginia Landmarks Commission is this large Federal style home with a two-level portico and rare flush-board siding. Two side wings were added in the 1940s. Built by Mr. John Gray and known as Gray's Folly. A large center hallway has an open stairway to the second floor.

properties.name: Santillane
properties.Desc: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places. A marker on US220 calls it 'one of Botetourt County's most distinguished properties.' The Greek Revival House sits on a tract of land originally owned by Colonel George Hancock, a member of the United States Congress from 1793 - 1797. The original 1795 structure burned in 1812 and the house you see today was completed in 1820. In 1808 Hancock's daughter, Judith, married General William Clark, who serve from 1803 - 1806 as a leader of Thomas Jefferson's famous Lewis and Clark Expedition which was instrumental in opening the West for American settlement. Clark reportedly named the Judith River in Montana after the young girl he left in Fincastle while he sought a route to the Pacific.

properties.name: The Big Spring
properties.Desc: A public watering place from Indian days, it was part of the land granted by King George III to Isreal Christian, who included it in the original boundaries of Fincastle in 1770. Water Street served as a market area for vendors and Back Street was known as Jackey Alley for horse trading. In 1979, HFI built a Gazebo at a cost of $3,500. The park is now owned and maintained by the Town of Fincastle.
